item.title: At War Blog: Battlefield Update: The Fight for Isolated Government Outposts in Northern Syria
item.description: As world leaders and commentators of every stripe have debated President Obama’s “red line,” there have been significant developments on the ground.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan Aboud and Abu Ayman, two commanders of Islamist fighting units.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Science Tackles Mystery of the Teenage Brain
item.description: New research at Cambridge University will look into the changes in the brain that are responsible for and provide early warning of mental health problems.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: An image of the human brain created by scanning technology.

item.title: India Ink: In Andhra, Maoist Rebels Pin Hopes on Memories of the Dead
item.description: Maoist leadership is facing a crisis, mainly because most of the top rebel leaders have either been killed or arrested in the last few years.
item.dc:creator: By RAHUL PANDITA
item.media:description: A police poster with photos of wanted Maoist leaders outside Birpur, Andhra Pradesh, the native place of Maoist leader Ganapathi, April 2010.

item.title: European Commission Warns of Trade Case Against China
item.description: The new complaint would involve makers of mobile telecommunications equipment, but the commission said it would first try to negotiate with Chinese authorities.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Europeans Move to Stave Off Hollywood
item.description: Talks on a trade pact between Europe and the U.S. have yet to start, but already European governments and filmmakers are complaining that it could mean a blow for European culture.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Cannes, France, is preparing for the opening on Wednesday of the 66th edition of its film festival. In a nod to American cinema the official poster features Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward.

item.title: Japanese Reactor Is Said to Stand on Fault Line
item.description: Seismologists directed by Japan’s new nuclear regulator said the fault showed signs of being geologically active, suggesting a high earthquake risk.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Arctic Council Adds Six Members, Including China
item.description: Deposits of oil, gas and minerals in the region have set off a global competition for influence and economic opportunities.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: DealBook: Uninvited Guest Jolts Japan’s Business Culture
item.description: The hedge fund manager Daniel Loeb’s demands of Sony could test Japan’s commitment to economic change.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Sony's entertainment unit includes a film studio and one of the largest music labels in the world, featuring artists like Taylor Swift.

item.title: Euro Zone Economy Shrinks; Recession Returns in France
item.description: The 17-nation monetary union contracted more than expected at the start of 2013, the sixth straight quarterly decline, as France continued to shrink and Germany grew slightly.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Taiwan Recalls Envoy in Manila Over Killing
item.description: Taiwan also said it had stopped accepting applications for Filipino workers, retaliating for the killing of a fisherman by the Philippine Coast Guard.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: At United Nations, Cameron Mulls Dissent Back Home
item.description: With Prime Minister David Cameron scheduled to debate global poverty in New York, dissidents in London were demanding a vote on Britain’s relationship with the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and ALAN COWELL

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 15
item.description: Hopes dim for peace in Syria; Russia kicks out an American spy; the Cannes film festival is set to open; and strange allies unite to save Olympic wrestling.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: An image from Bayda, Syria, released by a group, the Syrian Revolution Against Bashar Assad.

item.title: India Ink: Meet the Upwardly Mobile Middle-Class Indian
item.description: The Chile family’s struggle to break into the middle class spanned more than six decades.
item.dc:creator: By SAMBUDDHA MITRA MUSTAFI
item.media:description: Yogesh Chile, far right, with his family in their apartment in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: India Ink: Should India Provide Direct Military Aid to Afghanistan?
item.description: New Delhi could provide stability in Afghanistan through military assistance after international forces leave, a foreign policy analyst argues.
item.dc:creator: By JAVID AHMAD
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, right, with Afghan President Hamid Karzai at the Hyderabad House in New Delhi on Jan. 12, 2009.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 14
item.description: A beekeeper handling an artificial hive on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A beekeeper handling an artificial hive full of honeybees at a farm on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

item.title: Working Abroad After Retirement Gains Appeal
item.description: Attracted by lower costs of living, more retirees seem to be moving to Latin America and the Caribbean, but they are becoming entrepreneurs and continuing their professions remotely.
item.dc:creator: By KERRY HANNON
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrice Wynne, a former independent bookstore owner in California, now owns Abrazos, a retail shop in San Miguel de Allende in Mexico.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Under Siege at Home, Refugees Are Feared Lost at Sea
item.description: A crowded boat capsized while trying to escape a cyclone bearing down on Myanmar, tossing dozens of Rohingya Muslims into the sea, the United Nations said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Brazilian Court Council Removes a Barrier to Same-Sex Marriage
item.description: The council ruled on Tuesday that notary publics could not refuse to perform same-sex marriage ceremonies, a decision that effectively legalizes gay marriage.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Op-Docs: ‘A Long Ride Toward a New China’
item.description: Every summer, the blogger "Tiger Temple" bikes around China to report on rural news stories censored by state-run media.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN MAING

item.title: Wal-Mart Announces Its Own Factory Safety Plan in Bangladesh
item.description: Wal-Mart, rejecting a safety plan backed by more than a dozen European companies, said its monitors would “conduct in-depth safety inspections” at all factories it uses in Bangladesh.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:description: Photo of a production order for jeans to be sold at Walmart that the Bangladesh Center for Worker Solidarity said it found in the rubble after the Rana Plaza building collapse in Bangladesh.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Deputy President Promises to Cooperate With International Court
item.description: William Ruto promised the International Criminal Court on Tuesday that he and President Uhuru Kenyatta would cooperate, despite calling the charges against them the result of a “conspiracy of lies.”
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: State of Emergency Declared
item.description: Admitting that Islamist extremists now control some of his nation’s villages and towns, President Goodluck Jonathan declared a state of emergency on Tuesday across Nigeria’s troubled northeast.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russia Expels American, Saying He Is a C.I.A. Officer
item.description: Russian officials said Ryan C. Fogle was an officer of the Central Intelligence Agency who had been caught trying to recruit a Russian to spy for the United States.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Wig askew, a man identified as Ryan C. Fogle, a diplomat, was arrested in Moscow. The low-tech evidence raised questions.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mine Strikes Resume
item.description: Workers at the world’s No. 3 platinum producer, Lonmin, began a wildcat strike on Tuesday, prompting fears of a return to the violence that rocked the industry last year.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: New Virus Spreads
item.description: Saudi Arabia has confirmed six new cases of the SARS-like coronavirus in its Eastern Province in recent days, the state news media reported.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
